facts.text: Civil Appeal Nos. 1353 to 1355 of 1967 filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal Nos. 1353 to 1355 of 1967. Appeals by certificate from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals by certificate from judgment and award dated 15th September 1966 of Mysore High Court in Misc. First Appeals Nos. 199 to 201 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by certificate from the judgment and Award dated 15th September 1966 of the Mysore High Court at Bangalore in Misc. First Appeals Nos. 199 to 201 of 1963.

facts.text: Three appeals by three Khatedars whose lands acquired for submersion area of Linganmakki reservoir in Mysore State.

anchor.surface_text: These three appeals, by certificate, are by three Khatedars, whose lands were acquired for the submersion area of the Linganmakki reservoir in Mysore State.

facts.text: Acquired lands were all wet lands measuring 29 acres and 37 guntas, 3.32 acres and 8.20 acres respectively.

anchor.surface_text: The areas so acquired were all wet lands and measured 29 acres and 37 guntas, 3.32 acres and 8.20 acres respectively.

facts.text: Special Land Acquisition Officer classified lands into rain-fed and tank-fed lands.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Land Acquisition Officer classified these lands into rain- fed and tank-fed lands, i.e. one crop and two crop lands,

facts.text: SLAO fixed Rs. 600 per acre for tank-fed wet lands and Rs. 500 per acre for rain-fed wet lands by capitalising annual rent.

anchor.surface_text: and adopting the method of valuation of capitalising the annual rent paid to the appellants fixed Rs. 600 per acre for the tank-fed, i.e., perennially irrigated wet lands, and Rs. 500 per acre for the rain-fed wet lands.

facts.text: SLAO found average annual rent 1-1/2 pallas of paddy per acre, gross rent Rs. 37.50 at Rs. 25 per palla, net Rs. 30 per acre after deductions.

anchor.surface_text: He arrived at these figures on, a finding that the average annual rent in respect of these lands was 1-1/2 pallas of paddy per acre which meant that the gross rent was Rs. 37.50 at the rate of Rs. 25 per palla. Deducting land revenue and bad debts he found that the net annual income was Rs. 30 per acre.

facts.text: Appellants referred under sec. 18 Land Acquisition Act to District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: On a reference by the appellants under sec. 18 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894, the District Judge increased the valuation

facts.text: District Judge increased valuation to Rs. 2500 per acre tank-fed and Rs. 2000 per acre rain-fed by capitalising net income 20 years.

anchor.surface_text: the District Judge increased the valuation to Rs. 2500 per acre for tank-fed lands and Rs. 2000 per acre for the rain-fed lands. The District Judge also adopted the method of valuation by capitalising the income by 20 years.

facts.text: District Judge capitalised whole net income instead of only rent payable to appellants.

anchor.surface_text: But what he did was to take the whole of the net income arising from the lands instead of capita- lising, only the rent payable to the appellants by the tenants of some of, the lands.

facts.text: Acquisition Officer appealed District Judge awards to Mysore High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In appeals filed by the Acquisition Officer against the awards by the District Judge, the, High Court of Mysore reduced the companypensation

facts.text: High Court reduced compensation to Rs. 1250 per acre for all lands irrespective of type or cultivation.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court of Mysore reduced the companypensation to Rs. 1250 per acre for all the lands, irrespective of whether they were tank-fed or rain- fed lands or whether they were self-cultivated or cultivated by tenants.

facts.text: High Court based Rs. 1250 on average rent 2-1/2 pallas paddy at Rs. 25 per palla capitalised 20 years.

anchor.surface_text: This. the High Court did on the footing that the income from the land was represented by the rent paid by the tenants. in respect of some of the lands, that such rent on an average came to 2-1/2 pallas of paddy and that at the rate of Rs. 25 per Dalla, by capitalising the rent by 20 years, the companypensation would companye to Rs. 1250 an acre.

facts.text: High Court awarded interest at 6% per annum.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court., in addition, awarded interest at 6 per annum on the amount of companypensation awarded by it.

facts.text: Land measuring 7 acres 10 guntas subject of Civil Appeal No. 1354 of 1967 and part of lands in C.A. No. 1353 not cultivated by tenant but under Khatedars personal cultivation.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also rejected the argument that the land measuring 7 acres 10 guntas, which is the subject-matter of Civil Appeal No. 1354 of 1967 and part of the lands which are the subject matter of C.A. No. 1353 of 1957 were number cultivated by any tenant and were in fact under the Khatedars personal cultivation

facts.text: Notifications under sections 4 and 6 of Land Acquisition Act issued in April and August 1960.

anchor.surface_text: by the time the numberifications under secs. 4 and 6 of the Act were issued,  in April and August 1960 , the Mysore Tenancy Act XIII of 1952 had companye into force.

facts.text: Mysore Tenancy Act XIII of 1952 came into force before notifications.

anchor.surface_text: the Mysore Tenancy Act XIII of 1952 had companye into force. Sec. 4 of that Act provided that a person lawfully cultivating any land belonging to another person shall be deemed to be a tenant

facts.text: Tenants were annual tenants but deemed tenants under tenancy laws with secured tenure.

anchor.surface_text: We do number know whether by the expression annual tenants we meant that their tenancy was for one year only and would lapse on the expiry of the year. Even if it were so, by the time the numberifications under secs. 4 and 6 of the Act were issued,  in April and August 1960 , the Mysore Tenancy Act XIII of 1952 had companye into force.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court judgment and remands for fresh calculation of compensation.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, allow the appeals, set aside the judgment of the High Court and remand these, appeals to the High Court for a fresh calculation of companypensation in the light of the observation,-, hereinabove made and in accordance with law.

facts.text: High Court erred in applying uniform rate of Rs. 1250 per acre to all lands including personally cultivated ones.

anchor.surface_text: The question raised before us is whether the High Court followed a companyrect principle while awarding an uniform rate of companypensation for all the acquired lands.

facts.text: No notices issued to tenants by SLAO or District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: Even in respect of lands cultivated by tenants, numbernotices appear to have been issued to them either by the Special Acquisition Officer or by District Judge though some of them did appear as witnesses

facts.text: Mysore Tenancy Act amended by Acts 16 of 1957, 24 of 1962, 12 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The Mysore Tenancy Act, 13 of 1952 was amended first by Mysore Act, 16 of 1957, and again by Mysore Acts 24 of 1962 and 12 of 1963.

facts.text: Mysore Tenants Temporary Protection From Eviction Act 37 of 1961 in force till March 31, 1962 or later.

anchor.surface_text: In 1961, the Mysore Legislature passed the Mysore Tenants  Temporary Protection From Eviction  Act, 37 of 1961. The Act was to remain in force till March 31, 1962

anchor.surface_text: The question raised before us is whether the High Court followed a correct principle while awarding an uniform rate of companypensation for all the acquired lands.

issues.text: Whether the tenants acquired as a result of the tenancy provisions any share in the compensation

anchor.surface_text: The point, therefore, is whether they acquired as a result of these provisions any share in the companypensation.

issues.text: Whether lands under tenants' cultivation and lands under personal cultivation by claimants should be valued on the same basis

But where the acquired land has been under the personal cultivation of a claimant, the annual rent obtained by him from a tenant from another land may number be the companyrect or real income obtainable by the claimant.

He arrived at these figures on, a finding that the average annual rent in respect of these lands was 1-1/2 pallas of paddy per acre which meant that the gross rent was Rs. 37.50 at the rate of Rs. 25 per palla. Deducting land revenue and bad debts he found that the net annual income was Rs. 30 per acre.

arguments.claim: The District Judge erred by capitalizing the whole net income instead of only the rent payable to landlords, as tenant's share includes labor costs.

anchor.surface_text: In modifying the District Judges award and reducing the rate, of companypensation to Rs. 1250 an acre. the High Court rejected the measure adopted by the District Judge, viz,., that the geni  rent  plus the quantity which the tenant would retain- for himself would be the net average in companye of the land. According to the High Court, the District Judge overlooked the fact that the tenant who get some income by cultivating the land did so because he and the members of his family had to expend labour thereon, and that therefore, both the expenses of cultivation as, also the value of such labour expended by the tenant ought to be taken into companysideration.

arguments.claim: Tenants' claims to compensation share may be barred by limitation under s.18 Land Acquisition Act, as they knew of acquisition but did not apply to be parties.

anchor.surface_text: This is, of-course. sub- ject to the bar of limitation under s. 18 of the Act-, for, it would prima facie appear that the tenants by appearing as witnesses for the claimants knew of the acquisition and the award and yet had made numberapplication to be made parties to the reference before the District Judge.

arguments.claim: Even if tenants not entitled to share, tenant-cultivated and self-cultivated lands cannot be valued the same.

anchor.surface_text: Even if it is found that the tenants are number entitled to. any share in the companypensation, the lands under tenants cultivation and those personally cultivated by the, claimants cannot be. valued on the same footing for the grounds set out earlier.

holdings.text: The High Court was in error in equating the lands cultivated by the tenants and those under the personal cultivation of the claimants and applying to both a uniform measure, viz., the annual rent obtained from the former for fixing compensation.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the High Court was in error in equating the lands cultivated by the tenants and those under the personal cultivation of the claimants and applying to both a uniform measure, viz., the annual rent obtained from the former for fixing companypensation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Uniform rent capitalization ignores difference in net returns: tenant rent nets tenant labor/costs, self-cultivation nets owner labor/costs; two types require separate treatment.

holdings.text: The two kinds of lands ought to have been separately treated and even if the rent in the cases of tenant-occupied land was taken as a measure for such land, that could not properly be the measure for arriving at the market value of the land under the claimants personal cultivation.

anchor.surface_text: The two kinds of lands ought to have been separately treated and even if the rent in the cases of tenant-occupied land was taken as a measure for such land, that could not properly be the measure for arriving at the market value of the land under the claimants personal cultivation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Market value via capitalization must reflect actual income derivation method specific to cultivation type; rent not proxy for self-cultivated income.

holdings.text: In view of these provisions the Special Land Acquisition Officer and the District Judge ought to have ascertained whether the tenants had any interest in the land and whether they were entitled to any share in the compensation payable in respect of lands under their cultivation.

anchor.surface_text: In view of these provisions the Special Land Acquisition Officer and the District Judge ought to have ascertained  which neither of them did  whether the-tenants had any interest in the land and whether they were entitled to any share in the companypensation payable in respect of lands under their cultivation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tenancy laws deemed cultivators tenants with secured tenure; acquisition authorities must determine apportionment of compensation per interests.

holdings.text: Even if it is found that the tenants are not entitled to any share in the compensation, the lands under tenants cultivation and those personally cultivated by the claimants cannot be valued on the same footing for the grounds set out earlier.

anchor.surface_text: Even if it is found that the tenants are number entitled to. any share in the companypensation, the lands under tenants cultivation and those personally cultivated by the, claimants cannot be. valued on the same footing for the grounds set out earlier.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Valuation distinction mandatory regardless of tenant compensation entitlement, based on differing net income calculations.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals allowed; High Court judgment set aside; remanded to High Court for fresh calculation of compensation separately for tenant-cultivated and personally cultivated lands, considering tenants' possible share if any.
directions: remand these appeals to the High Court for a fresh calculation of compensation in the light of the observations hereinabove made and in accordance with law
If for that purpose it may become necessary in the opinion of the High Court for fresh evidence to be led, parties may be given liberty to adduce such further evidence
Costs of these appeals will abide by the result in the High Court
